message_1: Consider the Fano variety $V$ of lines on a smooth cubic 3-fold in $\mathbb{P}^4$. Find the degree of $V$ and the number of connected components that $V$ has.
message_2:
The Fano variety $V$ of lines on a smooth cubic 3-fold $X$ in $\mathbb{P}^4$ is a smooth, irreducible variety of dimension 2. To find the degree of $V$, we can use the fact that the degree of the Fano variety of lines on a smooth cubic 3-fold is equal to the third Chern class of the tangent bundle of the 3-fold.

For a smooth cubic 3-fold $X \subset \mathbb{P}^4$, we have the following short exact sequence of sheaves:

$$0 \to \mathcal{O}_X \to \mathcal{O}_X(1)^{\oplus 5} \to T_X \to 0$$

Taking the third exterior power of this sequence, we get:

$$0 \to \bigwedge^3 T_X \to \bigwedge^3 \mathcal{O}_X(1)^{\oplus 5} \to 0$$

Now, we can compute the third Chern class $c_3(T_X)$ as the Euler characteristic of the sheaf $\bigwedge^3 T_X$. Using the above short exact sequence, we have:

$$c_3(T_X) = \chi(\bigwedge^3 T_X) = \chi(\bigwedge^3 \mathcal{O}_X(1)^{\oplus 5})$$

Using the binomial theorem, we can compute the Euler characteristic of the right-hand side:

$$\chi(\bigwedge^3 \mathcal{O}_X(1)^{\oplus 5}) = \binom{5}{3}\chi(\mathcal{O}_X(3)) = 10\chi(\mathcal{O}_X(3))$$

Now, we can use the Hirzebruch-Riemann-Roch theorem to compute the Euler characteristic of $\mathcal{O}_X(3)$:

$$\chi(\mathcal{O}_X(3)) = \int_X c_1(\mathcal{O}_X(3))\cdot c_2(T_X) = \int_X 3H\cdot c_2(T_X)$$

Here, $H$ is the hyperplane class of $X$. Since $X$ is a smooth cubic 3-fold, we have $c_2(T_X) = 10H^2$. Thus,

$$\chi(\mathcal{O}_X(3)) = \int_X 3H\cdot 10H^2 = 30\int_X H^3 = 30\cdot 3^3 = 270$$

Finally, we can compute the degree of the Fano variety $V$:

$$\deg(V) = c_3(T_X) = 10\chi(\mathcal{O}_X(3)) = 10\cdot 270 = 2700$$

As for the number of connected components of $V$, since $V$ is a smooth, irreducible variety, it has only one connected component.
